entry.title: Libre/Open blockchain / cryptographic ASICs
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the substantial energy consumption associated with Bitcoin mining and its broader implications. It highlights an ongoing concern that despite efforts to improve energy efficiency per watt, the overall energy consumption continues to escalate. This paradox is particularly evident in the context of Beowulf clusters and the computational demands of Bitcoin mining, where optimizing for performance per watt does not necessarily reduce total energy consumption. In fact, this optimization leads to an "arms race" in computing power, encouraging the development and use of more advanced, energy-intensive hardware.
This competitive escalation has significant repercussions for the decentralization and security of Bitcoin. As the production and operational costs for cutting-edge ASICs (Application-Specific Integrated Circuits) skyrocket – with 3nm geometry production masks costing around USD 16 million – the ability to participate in Bitcoin mining becomes restricted to a handful of players. This concentration of mining power not only contradicts the decentralized ethos of cryptocurrencies but also raises concerns about the potential introduction of hardware backdoors due to the limited number of entities capable of creating such specialized mining equipment.
Amid these challenges, there are initiatives aimed at mitigating the environmental impact of technology and promoting sustainability within the industry. An example provided is a crowd-funded project focused on eco-conscious hardware, [Crowd Supply's EOMA68](https://www.crowdsupply.com/eoma68), which suggests a growing awareness and effort to address the environmental concerns associated with high-performance computing and cryptocurrency mining.
